keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a former Capitol rioter, was pardoned by President Trump in 2021 and later arrested in 2025 for threatening to kill U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.
Moynihan allegedly texted threats stating he would kill Jeffries, claiming he must be eliminated due to his political stance, including a message: 'I will kill him for the future.'
The arrest highlights concerns about the impact of blanket pardons on individuals who committed violent acts during the January 6 Capitol riot.
Moynihan was sentenced in 2023 to 21 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release, and was released under a full pardon along with over 1,500 others.

This incident reflects a broader pattern where individuals pardoned after the Capitol riot have committed new violent crimes, prompting concerns from law enforcement and lawmakers about public safety.
Capitol Police reported a significant increase in threat assessments, with 14,000 cases expected by end of 2025, signaling a growing threat to U.S. lawmakers.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Christopher Moynihan, a man pardoned by former President Trump after participating in the January 6, 2021 Capitol riot, has been arrested for allegedly threatening to kill U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. Court records show he sent texts stating he would kill Jeffries, claiming he must be eliminated due to political opposition. Moynihan, who was previously sentenced in 2023 to 21 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release, was released under a full pardon along with over 1,500 others. His arrest raises concerns about the safety of lawmakers and the long-term consequences of blanket pardons for Capitol rioters, especially given that law enforcement is now managing over 14,000 threat assessments related to violence against elected officials.
